Today, July 21, 2020, the Bertie County Board of Education unanimously approved the superintendent‚Äôs recommendation to open the school year on Plan C‚Äîall remote learning‚Äîfor the first nine weeks of school.
Face-to-face provisions will be made for certain groups of students such as those with an IEP, students enrolled in certain CTE courses with Martin Community College that require labs, and select seniors who need to ensure they have all their credits for graduation.
All Fall sports and extracurricular (after-school) activities such as band are suspended indefinitely.
As the close of the first nine weeks approaches, the situation in Bertie County will be reevaluated with regard to the spread and reach of the COVID-19 and another decision will be made for moving forward from that point.
More information is forthcoming about the plans for remote learning, meals, etc.

UPDATES FROM THE MEDIA CONFERENCE HELD BY GOV. ROY COOPER JULY 14, 2020:

School districts may operate on a specific hybrid plan (B), which implements both in-person and remote learning, OR districts may opt to do remote learning only (C).
In the upcoming school year, which is slated to begin August 17 for all schools, face coverings will be required for ALL students (K-12), staff and visitors during the school day.
All students (K-12), staff and visitors will be screened prior to entering a school or any school facility. (This includes temperature and symptom checklists.)
Governor Cooper extended the Phase 2 "Safer At Home" order through at least August 7 and encourages everyone, everywhere to wear face coverings, practice social distancing and practice proper handwashing techniques regularly.
More details to come! Stay tuned to the BCS social media sites and the BCS district website for more information ...

The last day of the mobile meal service that has been provided to children since March‚Äîas a result of the pandemic‚Äîis today, now that the official end of the school year has come.

There will be a short break in service until the traditional Summer Feeding Program begins.

Summer Feeding begins July 6th and will continue until August 7th

Notices were sent out for parents to request summer feeding. **If you did not receive a notice, please go to the Bertie County School Nutrition Facebook Page and inbox Mrs. Tiwana Smallwood, director. There, please leave your name, address and the number of children that will be in the household.

Due to the pandemic, our schools will only serve as prep sites for Summer Feeding. Meals will be served through a combination of service stops at particular sites out in the county, as well as house-to-house delivery. More information will be shared in the next couple of weeks.

Registration is NOW OPEN, and will remain open throughout the summer. The registration process will be handled through Eventbrite and is open to all youth, regardless if you are a 4-H member or not. Programs are FREE to access BUT there may be a cost associated with the materials needed for each program. Prior to the start of each program you register for, a materials list will be provided for you so you can determine what you already have at home or may need to purchase. Insight from Teaching with Poverty in Mind:
#WhatyareadingWednesday #BertieCountySchoolsVirtualSpiritWeek

During this time of unplanned worlds turned upside down, the very heart of this book is being displayed by school employees not only in Bertie County, but around this country. In chapter 3, it discusses by title embracing the mind-set of change. While the book is discussing how to reach students effectively, by changing what we are doing in order to literally change the brain, every educator is having to embrace the change right now. We are literally having to change everything that has been done and walk into a world unknown, but in the long run, this may be one of the most effective changes to affect education in this country, state, and in our county. Despite how others may see it, educators are rising to the challenge, and reaching out to the students. I think you will see the effects continue long after these covid days have passed.

Carla Pesce, M.Ed.
Exceptional Children's Teacher
Colerain Elementary School
